description: From the Middle English remorden, from the Anglo-Norman and Middle French remordre and its etymon the Latin remordeō, from re- + mordeō; compare the Catalan remordir, remordre, the French remordre, the Italian rimordere, the Old Occitan remordre, the Portuguese remorder, and the Spanish remorder.

verbs.description: remord (third-person singular simple present remords, present participle remording, simple past and past participle remorded)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To excite to remorse; to rebuke.
examples: Dyvers People That Remord This Rymyng Agaynst the Scot
